Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students: Grades, Data Driven Decision Making, Dropping out and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis
Abstract Note: School personnel currently lack an effective method to pattern and visually interpret disaggregated achievement data collected on students as a means to help inform decision making. This study, through the examination of longitudinal K-12 teacher assigned grading histories for entire cohorts of students from a school district (n=188), demonstrates a novel application of hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization in which all data points collected on every student in a cohort can be patterned, visualized and interpreted to aid in data driven decision making by teachers and administrators. Additionally, as a proof-of-concept study, overall schooling outcomes, such as student dropout or taking a college entrance exam, are identified from the data patterns and compared to past methods of dropout identification as one example of the usefulness of the method. Hierarchical cluster analysis correctly identified over 80% of the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8. (Contains 5 figures.)
Short Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students
Notes:
This article talks about how data analysis helps teachers and administrators make decisions according to students' data being collected.

 I agree that teacher-assigned grades can reveal more comprehensively about students' performance which is a better resource than just standard test scores.
Automatic Tags: data; data analysis; Decision Making; Dropouts; Elementary School Students; Grades (Scholastic); Identification; MULTIVARIATE analysis; School Districts; Secondary School Students

Author: Grunspan, Daniel Z.; Wiggins, Benjamin L.; Goodreau, Steven M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Abstract Note: Social interactions between students are a major and underexplored part of undergraduate education. Understanding how learning relationships form in undergraduate classrooms, as well as the impacts these relationships have on learning outcomes, can inform educators in unique ways and improve educational reform. Social network analysis (SNA) provides the necessary tool kit for investigating questions involving relational data. We introduce basic concepts in SNA, along with methods for data collection, data processing, and data analysis, using a previously collected example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial. We conduct descriptive analyses of the structure of the network of costudying relationships. We explore generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also test for an association between network position and success on exams. We also cover practical issues, such as the unique aspects of human subjects review for network studies. Our aims are to convince readers that using SNA in classroom environments allows rich and informative analyses to take place and to provide some initial tools for doing so, in the process inspiring future educational studies incorporating relational data.
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis
Notes: 1.In terms of finding out about students social networks, I wasn't thinking specifically of asking students to share their social networking accounts, but that might be part of it.  My initial thoughts came from observing the groupings (in seminar sessions and outside) that my students formed.  I distinctly remember two students who were struggling, but hung around together, went to the library together, sat in lectures together and came to tutorials together.  It appeared to me that they needed each other for support.  Tutorials were often unproductive, but neither of them appeared concerned, and I guessed this was perhaps because they used each other as reference points to check their own learning.  If one 'didn't get it' then perhaps the other one didn't feel so worried about also 'not getting it'  This is all speculation, but seeing this did make me wonder whether exploring the social networks (online and offline) of those students who were at risk of 'failing' had some mileage.  Then I realised that looking at the networks of all students was equally valid.

Author: Young, Jeffrey R.
Title: Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data
Publication Title: The Chronicle of Higher Education Blogs: Wired Campus
Notes:
I highly agree that students' cognitive developmental stages should be assessed in a more detailed way. According to associatists' theory of cognitive development, children's understanding and thinking are complexly developing. Learning not only requires one ability but multiple domain knowledge to process.

Learning analytics can be used in providing more detailed assessment of students' cognitive abilities. So I agree that "by giving educators detailed data on students and the ability to customize teaching materials so they truly can nurture the potential of every single individual."

This article reminds me that in cognitive science or psychology, theories most of the time can not be generalized to a broad scope. Sometimes, it's even case by case. So I understand Mr. Rose's proposal about "science of the individual". And agree with Mr. Rose's opinion by saying " you can’t actually tell anything in population studies about any individual in that group."

Trying to find multiple different patterns in a population is a better way than studying the average group in my eyes. Since the big data is growing fast in recent years, looking for patterns is becoming more realistic.

In addition, I agree that the contextualized profile of students' performance and what kind of support they need is something that educators and program developers need to pay attention to.

Besides, the comments of this TEDx talk are interesting too. Will come back and read again.

The real change will be effected by learners being empowered by their own data through making overt the processes of personalisation. The next question is how do we develop data literacy within educators and students to ensure that they can understand and make best use of the data about their own learning?

Author: Corbett, Albert T.; Anderson, John R.
Title: Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Abstract Note: This paper describes an effort to model students' changing knowledge state during skill acquisition. Students in this research are learning to write short programs with the ACT Programming Tutor (APT). APT is constructed around a production rule cognitive model of programming knowledge, called theideal student model. This model allows the tutor to solve exercises along with the student and provide assistance as necessary. As the student works, the tutor also maintains an estimate of the probability that the student has learned each of the rules in the ideal model, in a process calledknowledge tracing. The tutor presents an individualized sequence of exercises to the student based on these probability estimates until the student has ‘mastered’ each rule. The programming tutor, cognitive model and learning and performance assumptions are described. A series of studies is reviewed that examine the empirical validity of knowledge tracing and has led to modifications in the process. Currently the model is quite successful in predicting test performance. Further modifications in the modeling process are discussed that may improve performance levels.
Notes: I think analytical models based on which interventions are taken or at risk students are identified, should *not* become technically transparent to the students. Once students know what type of data collected from them is given more weightage, or what is the intrinsic rule structure of the model (however sophisticated it might be) , they would try to optimize/mold themselves according to it. This in my opinion is harmful simply because of the Campbell's law which states that :"The more any quantitative social indicator (or even some qualitative indicator) is used for social decision-making, the more subject it will be to corruption pressures and the more apt it will be to distort and corrupt the social processes it is intended to monitor". So I kind of disagree with what Prof Sharon Slade visualizes learning analytics' future where the teacher lets the student know what are the metrics based on which decisions are being made.
Automatic Tags: Education (general); empirical validity; individual differences; intelligent tutoring systems; Learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; mastery learning; Multimedia Information Systems; procedural knowledge; Psychology, general; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Siemens, George; Baker, Ryan S. J. d.
Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining: Towards Communication and Collaboration
Publication Title: Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge
Abstract Note: Growing interest in data and analytics in education, teaching, and learning raises the priority for increased, high-quality research into the models, methods, technologies, and impact of analytics. Two research communities -- Educational Data Mining (EDM) and Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) have developed separately to address this need. This paper argues for increased and formal communication and collaboration between these communities in order to share research, methods, and tools for data mining and analysis in the service of developing both LAK and EDM fields.
Short Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining
Notes:
1. What is learning analytics: “learning analytics is a fast growing area of Technology-Enhanced Learning (TEL) research. It is the measurement, collection, analysis and reporting of data about learners and their contexts, for purposes of understanding and optimizing learning and the environments in which it occurs.”

2. This article reminds me of the factors that driving the development of learning analytics:

- Big data(the growing datasets)—educational institution: technical challenge—extract value from the big datasets.

-Online learning (benefits and problems)—teachers and students:the educational challenges drive learning analytics to optimize opportunities for online learning.

-Political concerns(political/economic challenge)--governments:there is increasing demand for educational institutions to measure, demonstrate and improve performance—optimise learning and educational results at national or international levels.

3. The choice of target audience therefore affects how researchers conceptualize problems, capture data, report findings, act on their findings and refine their models.

4. Also learning analytics seems like emerging as a separate field in the recent years. The differences between learning analytics and academic analytics: learning analytics benefit learners and faculty and are focused at the level of courses and department; academic analytics benefit funders, administrators and marketing at institutional level.

5. I think there are some future challenges in this field.

  • Build strong connections with the learning sciences (learning analytics emerge from the wide fields of analytics and data mining, however, the role of learning science is under-represented)
  1. The importance of cognitive studies: understanding and optimizing learning requires a good understanding of how learning takes place, how it can be supported, and the importance of factors such as identity, reputation, and affect.
  2. Two way processes: Learning analytics benefits better learning design, effective pedagogy and increasing student self-awareness, and learning science directs learning analytics in dealing with data.
  • Develop methods of working with a wide range of datasets in order to optimize learning environments
  1. Use of combination o datasets enables researchers to analyze the problems learners face in different environments.
  • Focus on the perspectives of learners (visualize analytics that are personalized—BE CLEAR)
  1. The needs of the learners weigh much in learning analytics.
  2. Such a perspective has the potential to extend criteria for learning success beyond grades and persistence to include motivation, confidence, enjoyment, satisfaction and meeting career goals.
  3. In many cases, the analytics process will need to be transparent, enabling learners to respond with feedback that can be used to refine the analytics, and enabling them to see how their data are being used.
  • Develop and apply a clear set of ethical guidelines (IMPORTANT)
  1. Clarifying and ensuring learners’ rights regarding to their data is very critical.
  2. There is no agreed method for researchers to obtain informed and ongoing consent to the use of data and there are no standard procedures allowing learners to opt out or to have their analytic record cleared.

5. The reason I think it is more pertinent to LA is that LA-informed policy decisions are more likely than many others to affect social spaces, and social spaces are the ones that (historically) have largely been left relatively unbridled in education, at least compared to others. If LA-policies appear to be regulating a space that students have traditionally felt more free in, it could be seen as more of an intrusion than when data drives other policies.

6. One specific way I could see this happening is the use of learning analytics to make open-ended "rich" environments more classroom feasible, say through adaptive scaffolding or adaptive task selection, where "adaptive" in this sense may take into consideration the user's interests to make the task engaging. Currently, in the realm of high-stakes testing, open-ended environments are having a rough ride because accountability drives teaching practices, and it is a lot easier for more focused learning objects to get traction. People see something open-ended and they say "that's nice, but how do I know students could actually learn X, Y, and Z from it... and even if they can, wouldn't it take less classroom time to give them a chapter or problems that specifically develop X, Y, and Z?" Also, teachers are under extreme time-stress, so asking them to learn how to implement a non-traditional learning object can be a significant request.

If EDM and LA can make open-ended environments more practically functional, say by practical use of feedback/scaffolding, then it could lead to a major improvement in the learning experience.

7. I learned that educators, policy makers, parents, and educational technology developers etc. nowadays become more and more aware of the value of data analysis in education. Learning analytics helps enhance the learning experiences and outcome of students through presenting a clearer picture of students' cognitive growth, and providing reflections and evaluations towards both pedagogy and technology. As I understand it, learning analytics is trying to translate all the analysis into guidance to educators (apply into teachers' daily practice), learners, administrators, curriculum designers, etc. 

I found learning analytics super interesting is because it requires not only analyzing data statistically but also knowing cognition theories, sociology, computer science, etc. in order to apply the findings in practice. In other words, it requires analysts not just understanding what the data says but also being able to transfer the data's meanings into interventions based on different situations where social contexts are put into consideration. The multidisciplinary feature definitely enriches people's understandings of the nature of education. 

Since Learning Analytics is still in its very early stage, there are many gaps in the studies to be identified and filled up. I feel excited that the data are accumulating and the literature base is growing, while more institutions and scholars are joining this field and collaborating with each other to build up a system with more standard approaches. 

I am particularly interested in how to make use of learning analytics to design the curriculum and learning tools to improve students' metacognition. To be more specific, for example, to enhance students' self-regulatory learning and peer learning through learning analytics is what I eager to study. Besides data's influence on learning and teaching, I also want to explore data analytics' benefits on enhancing children's social emotional development.
Automatic Tags: Collaboration; educational data mining; learning analytics and knowledge

Author: Baker, Ryan S. J. d; Corbett, Albert T.; Roll, Ido; Koedinger, Kenneth R.
Title: Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system
Abstract Note: Some students, when working in interactive learning environments, attempt to “game the system”, attempting to succeed in the environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly. In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Our detector also distinguishes between two distinct types of gaming which are associated with different learning outcomes. We explore this detector’s generalizability, and find that it transfers successfully to both new students and new tutor lessons.
Notes:
1. "Game the system", defined as "“attempting to succeed in an educational environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly", is really an interesting topic to study in Learning analytics.

2. I agree that the risks exist that students might game the system when they are working in interactive learning environments.
Automatic Tags: Behavior detection; Cognitive tutors; Education (general); Gaming the system; Generalizable models; Interactive learning environments; Latent response models; Machine learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; Multimedia Information Systems; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Zheng, Alice
Title: Evaluating Machine Learning Models
Abstract Note: Data science today is a lot like the Wild West: there’s endless opportunity and excitement, but also a lot of chaos and confusion. If you’re new to data science and applied machine learning, evaluating a machine-learning model can seem pretty overwhelming...
Notes:
Combining machine learning with learning analytics is a popular trend in recent years. If machine learning is applied to analyze some of our data, we will end up with some sort of "models".

Notes about Adaptive Learning interaction:

ALI is an education tool that begins by guiding the learner through course tasks linearly. All users will begin at the same starting point. An assessment of course objectives proficiency will be completed at the beginning and end of the course. ALI asks for permission to collect the user’s interaction data. If the user declines the collection of data, the user will be provided an experience based on previously successful users’ maps based on formerly collected data. Dependent on decisions made by the student, ALI will provide a customised experience and flow, optimised for the success of that individual while maintaining equivalent course outcomes across users. 

As the learner embarks within ALI, (s)he will be asked to complete a task. To complete this task, the user will choose a method of engaging with the material from a collection of multimodal instructional strategies including: lecture, reading, audio, imagery/video, demonstration, discussion group, and practice, as well as considerations for social interaction, information processing strategies, prior knowledge and personality style (Brown et al 2005). Once the learner has completed the task, successfully or unsuccessfully, using a chosen technique, that technique will no longer be available for use in completing subsequent tasks until all of the other techniques have been utilised. After all of the techniques have been utilised, ALI will provide the successive information in the most productive dissemination format, and provide a real time information dashboard of the techniques that have been employed previously and their effectiveness. ALI will provide data about the current user as well as all previous users. The student will have the freedom to switch, or use multiple, dissemination strategies at any time.

ALI will collect and provide feedback regarding: success in completion of objectives, techniques employed, percentage of each technique employed, level of success with each technique type, and recommendations for further study in the dissemination classification of greatest aptitude.

This proof-of-concept prototype is the first step in what may become a dynamic and responsive platform that utilises learning analyticsand machine learning to create personalised learning experiences.

Author: Leong, B; Polonetsky, J
Title: Why Opting Out of Student Data Collection Isn’t the Solution
Abstract Note: In every privacy debate across every industry, the same questions arise about the rights of individuals to “opt-out” of their data being collected or used. So it should come as no surprise that the “when” and “how” of parent and student opt-outs of education data collection or use has become a robust
Notes:
I agree with the "how data collection helps students" part. Serving primary use is one necessary reason for collection students' data.

Also I agree that it's time to opt out when there are some secondary uses of data include sharing any student data for purposes unrelated to the educational and related activities that are expected by parents.

I also support that future supervise on students' data collection and analysis should be improved, though according to the article, it's hard to provide opt-out rights to parents since it might "disrupt the ability o data to be used for essential educational purposes".

I understand the conflict between the parents who are concerning about their privacy rights and the parents along with teachers and school administrators who are expecting to make use of the data collected for making good decisions about managing and teaching.

I think it's true that parents should reserve the rights to decline uses of their children's data if the data are used for unrelated activities for purposes other than education, though the resolution of education with the progress of data analysis should be supported.

There is a range of different ethical issues for learning analytics in education. For instance, there are some issues such as informed consent, interpretation of data, misuse of data, privacy, management of data, and so on. Therefore, we need to carefully attend to ownership of data and to personal privacy issues when we access to student’s data.  Also, learning institutions have to be transparent about how and with whom the information will be used and shared, under which conditions.

Author: Educause
Title: Why Is Measuring Learning So Difficult?
Abstract Note: Several higher education learning and assessment professionals discuss the difficulties of measuring learning.
Notes:
I highly agree that learning has been simplified for collecting data, though learning is a very complicated activity that can be influenced by multiple factors such as prior knowledge, mental status, mindset, executive functioning skills, motivations, cultural construct, etc. Those factors cannot be fully measured simply with the methods of psychological empirical studies.Therefore, expecting a simple indicator to measure learning is impossible. Also, learning cannot be just measured by behavior, though behavior change is one result of learning, however, learning happens without any changes in behavior.

We can not expect to analyze human beings like analyzing programming codes. The connections between learning behaviors and learning itself can be hard to observe sometimes. And the connections between cultural context and learning are hard to capture especially on online learning platforms.

I also agree that on MOOC platforms, one problem to analyze learning is the huge wide range of different levels of competencies of the learners and the purposes of them. So we have to go back to the definition of learning and see what learning means to a person. The major two features that have been measured nowadays are achievement and efficiency, though learning includes more than those two factors.

In addition, I agree that reminding the learners the connections that they already have in mind (though they haven't realized yet) is really important, which facilitate the development of their meta-cognition. Showing more possibilities to the learners about their learning should be one goal of Learning analytics.
Automatic Tags: Assessment; Education; educational assessment; EDUCAUSE; Higher Education; learners; Learning; Teaching and learning

Author: Hanneman, R.A.; Riddle, M.
Title: Chapter 1: Social Network Data
Notes:

5. The network data are for comparing the variables to reveal the relationships: similarities and dissimilarities.

"But a network analyst is also likely to look at the data structure in a second way -- holistically. The analyst might note that there are about equal numbers of ones and zeros in the matrix. This suggests that there is a moderate "density" of liking overall. The analyst might also compare the cells above and below the diagonal to see if there is reciprocity in choices (e.g. Bob chose Ted, did Ted choose Bob?). This is the second major emphasis of network analysis: seeing how the whole pattern of individual choices gives rise to more holistic patterns."

6. I agree that "There is one difference with most network data, however, that makes a big difference in how such data are usually collected -- and the kinds of samples and populations that are studied."

7. To be noticed, "Because network methods focus on relations among actors, actors cannot be sampled independently to be included as observations. If one actor happens to be selected, then we must also include all other actors to whom our ego has (or could have) ties. As a result, network approaches tend to study whole populations by means of census, rather than by sample (we will discuss a number of exceptions to this shortly, under the topic of sampling ties)."

8. My question is the relations of one actor could lead to many other relations which seems quite complicated to analyze. How to deal with the data if the relations are super complicated?

Author: Greller, Wolfgang; Drachsler, Hendrik
Title: Translating Learning into Numbers: A Generic Framework for Learning Analytics
Abstract Note: ABSTRACT With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples.
Notes:
I strongly agree that one of biggest challenges LA fields is/will be facing is the legitimacy of the collection and use of data. As the values of data increases along with the availability and accessibility of more and more advanced data-driven research methods and tools in LA, the ownership of every piece of data really matters to everyone who is possibly involved in the data creation and collection process. I actually read an article from my Normative Perspective of Learning and learners class last semester  that captured some interesting aspects regarding the nature of data. Some people think data is neutral and doesn't belong to anyone. In other words, it just floats in the universe and waits to be discovered. Another point of view is that data is only meaningful in the eye of the observers of those actions. In other words, it is the data-collecting agents actually entitled the data with values. These are two fairly idiosyncratic views I learned. I guess as the LA develops further, people will have to face more of these fundamental questions regarding who are responsible for what kinds of data, depending on what it came from and where it can be used. 

Despite the potential and possibility of data analysis, we are eventually challenged with the limitation of information overload due to the immense amount of information. Information overload, in fact, hampers scientists from performing novel experiments that can lead to key discoveries, because information lead them to duplicate similar experiments from the past. Thus, it is important to understand that data in Learning Analytics, whether big or small, do not reflect every aspect of our class, teacher, and students. Like this, since the immense data collected consistently need to be utilized as meaningful information or knowledge, data mining is gaining attention in the modern information and technology centric society. These knowledge or information can be applied widely not only to education, but also to areas, such as management, production management, research project, market analysis, technology design, and scientific investigation.

Also, I am certaint that gifted learners and disadvantaged learners need attention as the general student group. We can however begin to use analytics based interventions to address the needs and nature of gifted students and design learning experiences that help all students of varying achievement levels to address their deficiencies and hone their strengths.  In many states, the identification process for giftedness in K-12 often involves objective assessments which automatically excludes English language learners, the disabled, and students with low socio-economic status who may have basic skills deficiencies. If we can include both subjective and objective assessments that reveal who learners are as a whole person, we can design better learning experiences for all students.

Author: Kay, Judy; Maisonneuve, Nicolas; Yacef, Kalina; Reimann, Peter
Title: The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity
Abstract Note: We have created a set of novel visualisations of group activity: they mirror activity of individuals and their interactions, based upon readily available authentic data. We evaluated these visualisations in the context of a semester long software development project course. We give a theoretical analysis of the design of our visualizations using the framework from the “Big 5” theory of team work as well as a qualitative study of the visualisations and the students’ reflective reports. We conclude that these visualisations provide a powerful and valuable mirroring role with potential, when well used, to help groups learn to improve their effectiveness.
Notes:
I am really interested in the topic about studying teamwork, especially after a truly awful experience working with a "teammate" once (haha).

I agree with the definition of "teamwork" that "a set of interrelated thoughts, actions, and feelings of each team member that are needed to function as a team and that combine to facilitate coordinated, adaptive performance and task objectives resulting in value-added outcomes." Also, according to my unsuccessful teamwork experience, I agree with the "Big Five" components of teamwork, which are team leadership, mutual performance monitoring, backup behavior, adaptability, and team orientation. The three coordinating mechanisms (shared mental models, mutual trust, and closed -loop communication) that are needed for the five competencies to function make sense.
Automatic Tags: Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Computers and Education; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); Multimedia Information Systems; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Konstan, Joseph A.; Walker, J. D.; Brooks, D. Christopher; Brown, Keith; Ekstrand, Michael D.
Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale: Evaluation and Lessons Learned from a Hybrid MOOC
Short Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale
Notes:
I agree with the logic of the design that evaluating students' performance and improvement with surveys of demographics, self-assessed skills, knowledge-assessment tool, and learning intent, in order to get a clear picture. However, I always doubt if it's realistic to "explore the medium of massive-scale online education as vehicle for delivering in-depth advanced technical content at a level normally associated with a graduate -credit course" which is the intent mentioned in this article. In my eyes, MOOC courses can never replace the study in universities even though the courses share the same content and same instructors, however, learning is not only relying on course study, but is also related to other resources, such as school activities, classmates interactions, and also alumni support, etc.

Also, tracking students, and compare students who enrolled for credit with those who enrolled only for the free, open course is good idea for optimizing the system. However, my question is the resources for students who enrolled for credit are much more (includes extra materials, assignments, class discussions and teacher's in class facilitators) than those who only took coursera sessions.

 

Higher Education Commission (HEC)'s report ‘From Bricks to Clicks: the potential of data and analytics in Higher Education’.
Automatic Tags: learning assessment; Massively Online Open Course (MOOC)

Author: Desmarais, Michel C.; Naceur, Rhouma
Title: A Matrix Factorization Method for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices
Abstract Note: Uncovering the right skills behind question items is a difficult task. It requires a thorough understanding of the subject matter and of the cognitive factors that determine student performance. The skills definition, and the mapping of item to skills, require the involvement of experts. We investigate means to assist experts for this task by using a data driven, matrix factorization approach. The two mappings of items to skills, the expert on one side and the matrix factorization on the other, are compared in terms of discrepancies, and in terms of their performance when used in a linear model of skills assessment and item outcome prediction. Visual analysis shows a relatively similar pattern between the expert and the factorized mappings, although differences arise. The prediction comparison shows the factorization approach performs slightly better than the original expert Q-matrix, giving supporting evidence to the belief that the factorization mapping is valid. Implications for the use of the factorization to design better item to skills mapping are discussed.
Notes: A really interesting topic comparing the experts and the factorization mapping using Q metrics.
Automatic Tags: alternating least squares matrix factorization; Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Cognitive modeling; Computers and Education; Educational Technology; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); latent skills; Pedagogic Psychology; skills assessment; Student models; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Lane, H. Chad; Yacef, Kalina; Mostow, Jack; Pavlik, Philip

Author: Matsuda, Noboru; Furukawa, Tadanobu; Bier, Norman; Faloutsos, Christos
Title: Machine Beats Experts: Automatic Discovery of Skill Models for Data-Driven Online Course Refinement
Abstract Note: How can we automatically determine which skills must be mastered for the successful completion of an online course? Large-scale online courses (e.g., MOOCs) often contain a broad range of contents frequently intended to be a semester's worth of materials; this breadth often makes it difficult to articulate an accurate set of skills and knowledge (i.e., a skill model, or the QMatrix). We have developed an innovative method to discover skill models from the data of online courses. Our method assumes that online courses have a pre-defined skill map for which skills are associated with formative assessment items embedded throughout the online course. Our method carefully exploits correlations between various parts of student performance, as well as in the text of assessment items, to build a superior statistical model that even outperforms human experts. To evaluate our method, we compare our method with existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. The results show that (1) our method outperforms human-engineered skill models, (2) skill models discovered by our method are interpretable, and (3) our method is remarkably faster than existing methods. These results suggest that our method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability. [For complete proceedings, see ED560503.]
Notes: I am very curious about how adaptive machine learning can make a difference in education field.
Automatic Tags: Automation; Comparative Analysis; Correlation; data; Formative Evaluation; models; Online Courses; Skills

Author: Cortez, Paulo; Silva, Alice Maria Gonçalves
Title: Using data mining to predict secondary school student performance
Publication Title: Proceedings of 5th Annual Future Business Technology Conference
Abstract Note: Although the educational level of the Portuguese population has improved in the last decades, the statistics keep Portugal at Europe’s tail end due to its high student failure rates. In particular, lack of success in the core classes of Mathematics and the Portuguese language is extremely serious. On the other hand, the fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM), which aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data, offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain. The present work intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Recent real-world data (e.g. student grades, demographic, social and school related features) was collected by using school reports and questionnaires. The two core classes (i.e. Mathematics and Portuguese) were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks. Also, four DM models (i.e. Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines) and three input selections (e.g. with and without previous grades) were tested. The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. Although student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations, an explanatory analysis has shown that there are also other relevant features (e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption). As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.
Notes:
;

Through data mining, a student's learning data is collected and it develops a predictive model that plays a key role in building adaptive learning systems. Such adaptation or interventions can be used to predict students' future learning behavior and to change/adjust student’s learning activity.

http://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/blog/2014/jun/03/big-data-transform-university-learning

-What are currently the best known practices for: how we collect data, which data we collect, which data we ignore, how we interpret data, and how to actuate interpretations?

-I guess we also need to define effective in what regard and for who. Does effective mean an improvement in outcomes/attainment? In engagement/enjoyment? In predicting success? And who has the data been used by? Is it more effective for the teacher or the student (or, in K12, the parent) to be presented with and be able to effect actions on the basis of that data?

Title: Passing the Privacy Test as Student Data Laws Take Effect
Notes:
There is a distinction of when data is used to support the provider and when it is used to no benefit, or even in contradiction of the provider. Owner intention is key. We have seen the commodification of data across many mediums. Most individuals do not control where their data is going or how it is being used. We may want to provide a ‘meaningful contribution to scientific discovery’, but there is also a personal responsibility to make informed choices. We are increasingly accepting of relinquishing information, to whom we do not know.

http://blogs.kqed.org/mindshift/2012/07/how-will-student-data-be-used/

data privacy and data integration becomes a party. I think another important question to ask is, what do those 3rd parties want to do with the data? Title: Big Data in Education 7.1 Clustering
Notes:
How did we get these clusters:

1. decide how many clusters we want

2. pick starting values for the “centroids” of the clusters

3. classify every point as to which centroid it’s closest to.

4. re-fit the centroids as the center of the points in each cluster

5. repeat the process until the centroids stop moving

Title: Big Data in Education 7.2 Validation and Selection
Notes:
Distortion-Mean Squared Deviation

1. Take each point P

2. Find the centroid of P’s cluster C

3. Find the distance D from C to P

4. Square D to get D’

5. Sum all D’ to get Distortion

 

Distortion

-works for choosing between randomized restarts

-does not work choosing cluster size, because more clusters almost always leads to smaller

 

Using an information criterion:

1. assess how much fit would be spuriously expected from a random N centroids (without allowing the centroids to move)

2. assess how much fit you actually had

3. find the difference

Title: Big Data in Education 1.4 Classifiers Part 2
Notes:
1. Decision rules:Sets of if-then rules which you check in order.

2. Generating Rules form Decision Tree:

-create decision tree

-if there is at least one path that is worth keeping, go to 3 else go to 6

-take the "best" single path from root to leaf  and make that path a rule

-remove all data points classified by that rule from data set

-go to step 1

-take all remaining data points

-find the most common value for those data points

-make an "otherwise" rule using that

3. K* Good when data is very divergent

-Lots of different processes can lead to the same result

-Intractable to find general rules

-But data points that are similar tend to be from the same group

Title: Big Data in Education 2.2 Diagnostic Metrics Part 1
Notes:
;

1. Accuracy is not the best metrics: it does poorly when there is non-even assignment to categories

2. Computing Kappa

-interpreting Kappa

Kappa=0 agreement is at chance

Kappa=1 agreement is perfect

kappa=-1 agreement is perfectly inverse

Kappa > 1 you messed up somewhere

Kappa<0 your model is worse than chance; very rare to see unless you're using cross-validation; seen more commonly if you're using cross-validation

0<Kappa<1 for data mined models typically 0.3-0.5 is considered good enough to call the model better than chance and publishable

3. no magic number

Title: Big Data in Education 2.3 Diagnostic Metrics Part 2
Notes:
1. Four possibilities

True positive -both the model and the data say it's 1.

False positive-data says it's 0, but the model says it's 1.

True negative-both the data and the model say it's 0.

False negative-the data says it's 1, the model says it's 0.

2. very useful explanation of different types of models

3. A prime

4. Precision: the probability that a data point classified is actually true

Recall: the probability that a data point that is actually true is classified as true

5.

Title: Big Data in Education 2.4 Diagnostic Metrics: Correlation
Notes:
1. Linear correlation

1.0 perfect

0.0 none

-1.0 perfectly negatively correlated

In between depends on the field: small correlations ok in education

2. r squares (correlation)

a measure of what percentage of variance in dependent measure is explained by a model

3. RMSE/MAD

low RMSE/MAD high correlation good model

high RMSE/MAD low correlation bad model

high RSME/MAD high correlation model goes in the right direction, but is systematically biased

low RMSE/MAD low correlation model values are in the right range, but model does not capture relative change.

Title: Big Data in Education 2.5 Cross-Validation and Over-Fitting
Notes:

2. over fitting cannot be eliminated (every model is over fit in some fashion)

3. Assessing generalizability

-does your model transfer to new contexts?

-is it over-fit to a specific context

4. Training set /test set

-split your data into a training set and test set

-startified cross-validation

Title: Big Data in Education 4.2 Bayesian Knowledge Tracing
Notes:
1. Bayesian Knowledge Tracing (BKT)

-the classic approach for measuring tightly defined skill in online learning

-measuring how well a student knows a specific skill / knowledge component at a specific time

-Based on their past history of performance with that skill

2.

-each items must involve a single latent trait or skill

-each skill has four parameters

-from these parameters, and the pattern of successes and failures the student has had on each relevant skill so far

-can compute

3.  BKT only uses first problem attempt on each item

4. Typically, the potential values of BKT parameters are constrained.
